{"page_id": "1651ae21-78f5-80d3-9ddd-c62ed748a9bf", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "markdown": "Since **Twilio** is our service provider, any numbers that clients want to use in Gorgias must be ported into Twilio.

If the client already has numbers hosted on Twilio, the process is as follows:

1. Submit a porting reques**t**: The client needs to submit a porting request to Gorgias.

1. Coordinate transfer: We will organize the transfer of the number(s) from the client‚Äôs existing Twilio account to a subaccount linked to their Gorgias helpdesk.

This ensures the number is fully integrated with Gorgias for seamless usage while remaining hosted on Twilio.

> üö® IMPORTANT - please let the customer know that this process is not the same as regular number porting. It takes less time.

You can see the official procedure below, taken from

{"page_id": "2021ae21-78f5-80d2-a426-c21046f37558", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "markdown": "> üëâ These statuses only refer to inbound calls.

Previously, any inbound call not picked up by an agent was labeled as a ‚Äúmissed call,‚Äù even if the caller hung up before it reached an agent. For CX managers, this does not say much as they want to know if it‚Äôs a (1) staffing problem or a (2) training problem:

- Are people waiting to long in the queue & end-up dropping off = Workflow problem

- Are agents declining calls instead of picking them up = Staffing problem

Therefore, we introduced this change to differentiate and track **abandoned**, **missed**, and **cancelled calls:** 

<details><summary>**Missed calls: **A missed call occurs when an unanswered call rings at least one agent or is ended automatically by our system (ex. outside business hours) </summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

1. The call was routed to at least one agent and then ended **or **the call was automatically ended by our system due to agents not being available. 

- **Examples**:

- Call routed to available agents, but no agent answered 

- Call rang at least 1 agent and then was ended by the caller

- Call reached voicemail due to queue capacity or timeout.

- Call came in outside business hours and could not be answered.

<details><summary>**Abandoned calls: **An abandoned call occurs when the caller disconnects before the call is routed to an agent. </summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

1. The call was ended by the caller while in the queue, but before reaching any agent.  

1. Abandonment typically signals frustration, impatience, or unintentional disconnection.

- **Examples**:

- Caller hangs up during the greeting or IVR before entering the queue.

- Caller leaves the queue due to long wait times.

- Caller disconnects before reaching an agent or voicemail.

- **Notes: **

- While not currently relevant, if we ever start moving towards outbound dialers or even automated call back requests, there is a world in which outbound calls can have an ‚Äúabandoned state‚Äù. 

<details><summary>**Cancelled calls: **A canceled call is a call that is ended almost immediately after dialing (within 10 seconds of placing the call).</summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

- The caller actively decides to end the call, often shortly after initiating it.

- The call was not connected to an agent

- Typically reflects a conscious decision to end the call because of an error (e.g., the caller realizes they dialed the wrong number). 

- **Examples**:

- Caller hangs up immediately after dialing the number.

---

Really important reminder

[Link to page: 2c01ae21-78f5-8086-9d8c-c21831ab868f]

- Brands will see an¬†`increase in missed calls`¬†due to the use of this call status for calls that end with Play message or Forward to external number

- Brands may also see¬†`increase in canceled and abandoned calls`¬†due to the identification of spam calls through IVR tickets (earlier these type of calls wouldn't create tickets). There is a plan to improve the IVR system by limiting the repetition of the IVR message to five times before hanging up to avoid excessively long calls.

- Both of these just affect the metrics, not the billable tickets; project to improve Voice stats will be tackled in Q1 2026

- When creating the IVR menus,¬†`make sure to have all the options in the message`, as this is the only thing that's customer-facing. Listing the options in the numbered menu is just for internal purposes.

- By default we have the¬†`Go back option`¬†as #9. However, this also needs to be noted in the IVR message, so the customers are aware of it.", "block_count": 39, "blocks_raw": [{"object": "block", "id": "2021ae21-78f5-806f-8d36-d9a7022275ed", "parent": {"type": "page_id", "page_id": "2021ae21-78f5-80d2-a426-c21046f37558"}, "created_time": "2025-05-29T09:12:00.000Z", "last_edited_time": "2025-05-29T09:13:00.000Z", "created_by": {"object": "user", "id": "bc323ebe-d36d-485f-b55f-4cf02d796ebc"}, "last_edited_by": {"object": "user", "id": "bc323ebe-d36d-485f-b55f-4cf02d796ebc"}, "has_children": false, "archived": false, "in_trash": false, "type": "callout", "callout": {"rich_text": [{"type": "text", "text": {"content": "These statuses only refer to inbound calls.", "link": null}, "annotations": {"bold": false, "italic": false, "strikethrough": false, "underline": false, "code": false, "color": "default"}, "plain_text": "These statuses only refer to inbound calls.", "href": null}], "icon": {"type": "emoji", "emoji": "üëâ"}, "color": "gray_background"}, "parent_block_id": "2021ae21-78f5-80d2-a426-c21046f37558", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "source_page_id": "2021ae21-78f5-80d2-a426-c21046f37558"}, {"object": "block", "id": "2021ae21-78f5-80bf-a339-fd032da3b22b", "parent": {"type": "page_id", "page_id": "2021ae21-78f5-80d2-a426-c21046f37558"}, "created_time": "2025-05-29T09:13:00.000Z", "last_edited_time": "2025-05-29T09:14:00.000Z", "created_by": {"object": "user", "id": "bc323ebe-d36d-485f-b55f-4cf02d796ebc"}, "last_edited_by": {"object": "user", "id": "bc323ebe-d36d-485f-b55f-4cf02d796ebc"}, "has_children": false, "archived": false, "in_trash": false, "type": "paragraph", "paragraph": {"rich_text": [{"type": "text", "text": {"content": "Previously, any inbound call not picked up by an agent was labeled as a ‚Äúmissed call,‚Äù even if the caller hung up before it reached an agent. {"page_id": "1461ae21-78f5-80be-8701-c400ea0feb6c", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "markdown": "> üí° This page includes useful information about questions/issues that our customers might encounter when checking their **Voice stats**.

[Database: Voice Statistics]

In Support Perfromance Overview section, the Voice tickets are only reflected in the *Tickets Created* and *Tickets Closed* metric. All other relevant metrics for Voice tickets can be seen in Voice Overview and Voice Agent reports.

Yes, both metrics are available in Voice reports - both as an Overview and per Agent.

- **Outbound Calls**¬†- the total number of outbound calls placed

- **Inbound Calls¬†**-** **the total number of calls (answered and missed)

FRT calculations for phone (voice) tickets in the Support Performance Overview only account for text-based responses, such as emails or SMS. Phone calls alone do not contribute to FRT metrics, which may result in differences between actual response times and reported FRT.

---

<details><summary>1. How is FRT calculated for voice tickets</summary></details>

- FRT in Gorgias is only triggered by a text-based response.

- If an agent only answers a phone call and does not send an email or text message, the FRT remains unregistered for that ticket.

- If an email or text message is sent as a follow-up, that response is counted as the first response, even if the call was answered earlier.

- This can create discrepancies in FRT reporting, making voice-based support appear slower than it actually is.

---

<details><summary>2. Impact of this calculation method</summary></details>

- Phone calls answered do not count towards FRT unless followed up with a text response.

- The Support Performance Overview may show higher FRT averages than reality because calls without follow-up emails are ignored in the calculation.

---

- Support Performance Overview: FRT may appear artificially high for phone tickets.

- Voice Overview Report: The *average wait time* metric accurately reflects how long customers wait for an agent to answer a call.

- This metric should be used instead of FRT when evaluating voice support performance.

---

<details><summary>3. Best practices to improve FRT accuracy for voice tickets (workarounds)</summary></details>

- The client can introduce a text-based follow-up (email or SMS) is sent after handling a voice ticket to trigger FRT tracking.

- The client can use the Voice overview *average wait time* instead of FRT for evaluating phone support responsiveness.

---

As a final step, please submit product feedback if the client emphasises that this is extremely important for their business.

> üëâ These statuses only refer to inbound calls.

Previously, any inbound call not picked up by an agent was labeled as a ‚Äúmissed call,‚Äù even if the caller hung up before it reached an agent. For CX managers, this does not say much as they want to know if it‚Äôs a (1) staffing problem or a (2) training problem:

- Are people waiting to long in the queue & end-up dropping off = Workflow problem

- Are agents declining calls instead of picking them up = Staffing problem

Therefore, we introduced this change to differentiate and track **abandoned**, **missed**, and **cancelled calls:** 

<details><summary>**Missed calls: **A missed call occurs when an unanswered call rings at least one agent or is ended automatically by our system (ex. outside business hours) </summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

1. The call was routed to at least one agent and then ended **or **the call was automatically ended by our system due to agents not being available. 

- **Examples**:

- Call routed to available agents, but no agent answered 

- Call rang at least 1 agent and then was ended by the caller

- Call reached voicemail due to queue capacity or timeout.

- Call came in outside business hours and could not be answered.

<details><summary>**Abandoned calls: **An abandoned call occurs when the caller disconnects before the call is routed to an agent. </summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

1. The call was ended by the caller while in the queue, but before reaching any agent.  

1. Abandonment typically signals frustration, impatience, or unintentional disconnection.

- **Examples**:

- Caller hangs up during the greeting or IVR before entering the queue.

- Caller leaves the queue due to long wait times.

- Caller disconnects before reaching an agent or voicemail.

- **Notes: **

- While not currently relevant, if we ever start moving towards outbound dialers or even automated call back requests, there is a world in which outbound calls can have an ‚Äúabandoned state‚Äù. 

<details><summary>**Cancelled calls: **A canceled call is a call that is ended almost immediately after dialing (within 10 seconds of placing the call).</summary></details>

- **Key characteristics**:

- The caller actively decides to end the call, often shortly after initiating it.

- The call was not connected to an agent

- Typically reflects a conscious decision to end the call because of an error (e.g., the caller realizes they dialed the wrong number). 

- **Examples**:

- Caller hangs up immediately after dialing the number.

---

Really important reminder

[Link to page: 2c01ae21-78f5-8086-9d8c-c21831ab868f]

- Brands will see an¬†`increase in missed calls`¬†due to the use of this call status for calls that end with Play message or Forward to external number

- Brands may also see¬†`increase in canceled and abandoned calls`¬†due to the identification of spam calls through IVR tickets (earlier these type of calls wouldn't create tickets). There is a plan to improve the IVR system by limiting the repetition of the IVR message to five times before hanging up to avoid excessively long calls.

- Both of these just affect the metrics, not the billable tickets; project to improve Voice stats will be tackled in Q1 2026

- When creating the IVR menus,¬†`make sure to have all the options in the message`, as this is the only thing that's customer-facing. Listing the options in the numbered menu is just for internal purposes.

- By default we have the¬†`Go back option`¬†as #9. However, this also needs to be noted in the IVR message, so the customers are aware of it.

Why?

- Pulled automatically from **Business Hours**.

- No toggle to disable in Chat Settings.

- Text can be edited, but **icon + timer always show**.

---

Workarounds:

1. Edit default text (partial fix)

- Go to Settings ‚Üí Chat ‚Üí Language

- Update ‚Äúclosing soon / we‚Äôll be back at‚Äù message.

- Timer + icon stay visible.

1. Set 24-hour Custom Business Hours (full fix, but may be inconvenient)

- Enable Custom Business Hours or per Integration ‚Üí set to 24 h.

- Removes ‚Äúclosing soon‚Äù / ‚Äúwe‚Äôll be back at‚Äù.

- Chat always appears online.

---

{"page_id": "2c01ae21-78f5-8086-9d8c-c21831ab868f", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "markdown": "What customers are seeing:

1. Calls where the caller doesn‚Äôt press any IVR option now show as abandoned.

These used to be hidden. Most of them are spam, robocalls, or hang-ups.

1. Calls still listening to the IVR menu show as in routing.

Previously invisible, now surfaced properly.

Nothing changed in the customer‚Äôs IVR flow - only the visibility of these call types changed.

---

Many spam/automated numbers cannot receive callbacks, which is why outbound attempts appear broken or look like the agent is calling themselves.", "block_count": 9, "blocks_raw": [{"object": "block", {"page_id": "1621ae21-78f5-80f5-af34-cc994fc994f6", "parent_input_database_id": null, "parent_input_page_id": null, "markdown": "Yes, clients can port out a number created within Gorgias to another provider. The process requires a porting request to be initiated with the new carrier and coordination with Gorgias Support for approval.

---

Process for porting out a Gorgias number (porting away):

When a client is asking to move their phone numbers from Gorgias to a different platform, we want to provide them all the support they need for this transition. 

- If the number is a toll-free number, you can use the [Porting - Porting out: CSR and PIN for toll-free numbers](https://gorgias.gorgias.com/app/settings/macros/395292) macro

- If the number is not a toll-free number, there are a few steps that you need to follow: 

1. Use the [Voice - Porting out: Customer asking for CSR and PIN (email)](https://gorgias.gorgias.com/app/settings/macros/392121) macro. 

1. Make sure to populate in the Zap the required information (Account SID and phone number)

1. This will create a new ticket asking Twilio for the needed information. 

1. Assign the new ticket to yourself and snooze it for a couple of days. 

1. Send a reply to Twilio asking them to follow up in the same thread. 

1. Twilio tends to send replies in new threads and this creates duplicate tickets. 

![](https://prod-files-secure.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/d85b5c70-08ef-4ef0-ae0d-d01525f99c05/f951a2f8-0bfa-44f4-95dc-2e614e512a45/image.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Content-Sha256=UNSIGNED-PAYLOAD&X-Amz-Credential=ASIAZI2LB4664S36S67O%2F20251205%2Fus-west-2%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20251205T142849Z&X-Amz-Expires=3600&X-Amz-Security-Token=IQoJb3JpZ2luX2VjEJb%2F%2F%2F%2F%2F%2F%2F%2F%2F%2FwEaCXVzLXdlc3QtMiJHMEUCIB95rKIfk0qC04P%2BGlIgQ9nZSYkzUR5ARV5vvHoAXjYjAiEA5zQYO7jbYYA6sNUQqSd1xsFo3Qiti3zUz4g9zRfK%2FUAq%2FwMIXxAAGgw2Mzc0MjMxODM4MDUiDF3ZzQYid3gxTc6F2SrcA6y%2Ba6zPzWmhm3PKp0vnTaA7Zrm13ReP6dn6SWB0y%2BvEDHTiGeB1RzHE7SDXEHFwVtCvcHLR8mu%2B371TR%2F2U7mMKPlVtgb9k2szBhmmi0PuUvWWN3UdgAL6qJppu35mE67rZSg8hMSyybmNfzXNmubWnSR%2FPeLOtduqjRYFg2MXzC5%2Fmpc5cHxxFo%2B7tBCVFbH%2Bq6kqDsn6jwF2sd6N3wScqJqwMFx%2B98QRETutwqsxnpkjnAjQ7QanUrnKG3TXzJwRsZl2%2FcCPzVszZcMKNcrMz0KyET%2BJIK8I2seITfAeZ7s5ydw5MJrITby6vPAVohdOnCf0hOngic%2FyDI8jrmEvkSmDMRxVXE1ZR%2BHKOncYxYFS5ohOaDbCzXBbpy%2Foq1MgYgABF5FEnLkjLrisE%2BL0IijeUdUTQU2bHsML2OwwEuuhyirXWOu7Pg3180yOhtflM9ub70xGQHLnM01do78GyTx0rVhRNFlOK%2B0OMpkjyjO1jB3qcCz%2FRCASjlHOtLrnicmQkg0Q9FTI6QeNxmxNpCe0Vgo4%2BOAafhb7vbcZJoFjV%2FgObPTEom2d0FFx4j05Z7nU3fRhenUflZJo2KsoZT%2FRqdW%2BAI3enr6yFLzRwjw1acM7HPnnDferpMMrIy8kGOqUBWIYpzkolO86iOJmKwjrO1m9T5kc3ALBIto2lG7Xj1Oj4Y55u6Rogt2hS2yhZI6qBVW%2F8L3DVt6jgxErUghzre%2FF1XVajyOAltZUNonMKRztFNGKrVUGsq%2Fp1CJXMwk3n%2B9rVMtlKwqLldELMZk%2B%2Fx7H2%2FK0tD%2BIGt5wrjb3hi%2FMbN2g7dhMZMI0cLO%2BB5EL2ZsV3jM91iOqeGzJSCFLjcU820rlT&X-Amz-Signature=528d1b6adef60906104603adcad56c372dfe0dee9ec8980822552b49d746ce34&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-amz-checksum-mode=ENABLED&x-id=GetObject)

1. Once Twilio replies, you can follow back to the client using the [Porting - Porting out: CSR and PIN for local numbers](https://gorgias.gorgias.com/app/settings/macros/391984) macro

1. Make sure to add the information Twilio shared in their ticket. 

> ‚òéÔ∏è If you have any doubts, please reach out in #cross-phone-porting-help

---

- Porting out a number may take up to 7 business days depending on the carrier's processes.

- We do not charge any additional fees for porting out numbers, but the new carrier might have associated costs.

- If the client decides to port out their number, they will no longer be able to use Gorgias Voice features for that number.

1. Confirm whether the client is using V1 or V2 - 

[Link to page: 24f1ae21-78f5-803d-ae9e-db95462c25be]

1. If they are using V1, they can create a rule in Gorgias that can target message body words, such as ‚Äúvoicemail‚Äù, or ‚Äúincoming call‚Äù etc. same way as we would create any other rule.

1. If they are using V2, we cannot create auto-tag rules because the message body for V2 is in HTML, and rules cannot read HTML.

The only automatic tagging that happens on V2 tickets is coming directly from Aircall.

Navigate to Phone number > Settings. 1. Open Message Links. 1. Generate a link (e.g., https://wa.me/1234567890?text=Hello). This will be the link embedded in the chat widget. **‚Üí Step 2: Edit the Gorgias Chat widget code** To embed the WhatsApp button, add custom HTML into the Chat widget code snippet on the website. Common implementation patterns: - Adding a custom button in the chat greeting message. - Adding a persistent link inside the widget‚Äôs contact options. Merchants typically add something like: ```plain text Chat on WhatsApp ``` > üö® Note: The Gorgias widget does not have a built-in WhatsApp button. This requires inserting custom HTML or modifying the widget container on the site. **‚Üí Step 3: Test the link** After updating the widget snippet: 1. Open the website in a private window. 1. Launch the Gorgias Chat widget. 1. Confirm the WhatsApp link/button appears and opens WhatsApp correctly. --- Keep in mind: - Gorgias does not validate or host WhatsApp links; merchants must ensure they use the correct link from WhatsApp Business Manager. - Any styling or placement beyond default widget configurations is custom code and falls under advanced customisation. - If the link works outside the widget but not inside,
